unnormalised: One of the most frequent questions revolves around income tax slabs. These slabs determine the rate at which your income is taxed, and they often change with the annual budget presented by the Finance Minister. For FY 2023-24, there are two regimes – the old and the new. Under the new tax regime, for instance, income up to ₹3,00,000 is exempt, while income between ₹3,00,001 to ₹6,00,000 is taxed at 5%. Understanding which regime benefits you most is vital. Consider consulting a CA for personalized advice.

unnormalised: Then there are the deductions. Sec 80C allows deductions up to ₹1.5 lakh for investments like PPF, LIC, and ELSS. Section 80D provides deductions for medical insurance premiums. Claiming these deductions can significantly reduce your taxable income. Don't forget to keep all your receipts and documentation handy, as the IT Dept might request them. Deadlines are important to watch for!

unnormalised: The Goods and Services Tax (GST) is another important aspect. GST applies to most goods and services, with rates varying depending on the item. Businesses with a turnover exceeding ₹20 lakh (₹10 lakh for some special category states) are required to register for GST. Staying compliant with GST regulations is essential to avoid penalties. It's also worth noting that e-invoicing is mandatory for businesses with a turnover exceeding ₹5 crore w.e.f. 01/08/2023.

Staying compliant with G-S-T regulations is essential to avoid penalties. It's also worth noting that e-invoicing is mandatory for businesses with a turnover exceeding rupee five crore with effect from first august two thousand twenty three.
